intro: Salvia thymoides, commonly known as narrowleaf sage, is a perennial herb native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its slender, upright stems and small, gray-green, lance-shaped leaves. The plant produces spikes of violet to blue-purple flowers that bloom in summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, making it a hardy addition to xeriscapic gardens. Botanically, it belongs to the Lamiaceae family, sharing traits with other members like mint and rosemary.
